“Labeling” is a cognitive distortion where we attach simplified, sweeping judgments to people or situations based on just a few negative impressions. This narrow view ignores other factors and warps our perception of reality.

For example, calling someone “weird” or a “social outcast” just because of an unusual appearance. Likewise, labeling yourself can lower self-esteem by disregarding your positive qualities and achievements.

When we notice this distortion, we can assess people and situations more objectively, avoiding hasty and negative conclusions.
dialogSummary: This conversation centers on a man who was seen shouting at his children in the park. Person 1 quickly labels him as a “bad father” based on this single incident. Person 2 offers a more balanced perspective, pointing out that they lack enough information and that people can act differently depending on the circumstances.
dialog: I saw that man yelling at his kids in the park. He’s obviously a terrible father.
We can’t judge someone solely on one moment. Maybe he had a bad day or some reason for that outburst.
I’d never do that to my kids. He must be completely unfit as a parent.
It’s risky to make such sweeping judgments. People can behave differently under various conditions. In other circumstances, he might be a very caring father.
